title-group.article-title: The January Effect in the Corporate Bond Market: A Systematic Examination

abstract.p: This study examines the strength and causes of the January effect in the corporate bond market. The findings support a relation between this anomaly and the small-firm effect. The January effect is found to be a function of at least two phenomena. First, individual investors show a seasonal demand for noninvestment-grade bonds, but they show no such seasonal demand for investment-grade bonds. These findings are consistent with the increased strength of the January effect as bond rating declines. Second, the study demonstrates a shift in demand for higher-rated bonds at year-end that is related to institutional "window dressing."
